@ faisalislam you should talk to Pettis directly about what he thinks of Trump's trade and China policy.
It distracts us from the real but hard work of greatness: education, innovation, persuasion, sacrifice, compromise, patience, endurance.
The idea that one election, one filibuster, one Supreme Court appointment, or one man will make us "great" is a great illusion.
We have come to think of greatness as an entitlement - which is the worst form of American exceptionalism.
We don't want to be told that greatness takes effort, or thought, or sacrifice, or - God forbid - patience. We want instant, easy fixes.
A GOP friend told me yesterday, she thought Trump's popularity boils down to this: Americans today want short cuts to greatness.
China's addiction to piling up more and more capacity that's dependent on external demand to pay off is a serious weakness, not a strength.
Unfortunately, far too many of China's critics subscribe to the same mercantilist fallacies it does.
But the notion that, out of frustration, you take a sledgehammer to the global trading system is like using a machete to cure a cold sore.
I coordinated the compilation of a book, every year, listing in great detail the many unfair practices by China we were pushing to change.
I served as chairman of public policy committee for US Chamber of Commerce in Beijing, nobody has to "teach" me about unfair practices.
Merely "punishing" China, even that were effective, would damage a global trading system that benefits US immensely, in all sorts of ways.
Goal of US policy must be a China that consumes commensurate with its output, a difficult adjustment that's in their interests AND ours.
However, simply cutting off trade is NOT the solution to those imbalances, and would actually make things a lot worse for everyone.
Strangely enough, I agree with Navarro that trade/investment imbalances, including with China, ARE a central problem in the global economy.
